title: World Of Wearable Arts set to stun
text:
World Of Wearable Arts set to stun 
Sunday 20 Sep 2015 9:42 a.m. See the photo gallery 
Production rehearsals are under way at the venue for the World of Wearable Art Awards Show. 
New Zealand's largest arts show opens on Thursday and runs until October 11, boosting the Wellington economy and providing a platform to launch careers of designers from around the world. 
More than 50,000 people will see the two-hour show at the TSB Arena on Wellington which provides work for more than 200 models, dancers and performers. 
Designers of 108 garments compete for 40 awards with a total $165,000 worth of prizes. 
The Supreme WOW Award winner will receive $30,000 in prize money and a lot of media attention, including from international media. 
This year a new technology award recognises art pieces that merge technology and wearable art. 
Someone will also win a one-month internship at Cirque du Soleil in Canada and the winner of the Costume & Film Section receives a four-week internship at Weta Workshop. 
Winners are announced on Friday night. 
WOW's founder Dame Suzie Moncrieff is joined in the judging panel by Denise L'Estrange-Corbet, co-founder of the leading label WORLD, and New Zealand sculptor and artist Greer Twiss. 
Heather Palmer is competition director. 
The show: Aotearoa Section - designers use red, black, white to create a wearable work of art that explores the diverse cultures within New Zealand. Children's Section - designers discover an imaginary friend or re-create a special character. Man Section - designers create garments that revolutionise the uniform. Costume & Film Section - designs that reflect mythical worlds in the works of celebrated poets from other centuries or contemporary writers of science fiction. Digital Creative Excellence Section - costumes based on lines, curves and patterning created by celebrated architects. Avant Garde Section - for revolutionary, extravagant and extrovert works. Open Section - no thematic boundaries.
